sen.j: 巨勢派（こせは）とは、平安時代初期から室町時代を経て、明治時代まで連なる絵師の一族。
sen.e: The Kose school was a family of painters from the early Heian period, through the Muromachi, to the Meiji period.
The Kose school was a family of painters which existed from the early Heian period, through the Muromachi, to the Meiji period.
The Kose school was a family of painters which existed from the early Heian period, through the Muromachi, to the Meiji period.

sen.j: この流派は他の流派のように統一した画風を表わすものではなく、あくまで巨勢金岡に始まる家系・一門の画系を指す。
sen.e: This school represents not a single style of painting like other schools, but the painting styles created by KOSE no Kanaoka and succeeded by his family and pupils.
This school does not represent a single style of painting like other schools, but the various painting styles created by KOSE no Kanaoka and his descendants and pupils.
This school does not represent a single style of painting like other schools, but the various painting styles created by KOSE no Kanaoka and his descendants and pupils.

sen.j: もとは宮廷絵師であったが、第十二世永有が興福寺大乗院の絵仏師になって以降、子孫と絵仏師として家系を繋いだ。
sen.e: The family started as a court painter, but since the 12th head, Nagamochi, became a priest painter of Buddhist images of the Kofuku-ji Temple, he and his descendants had carried on the same profession.
The family started out as court painters, but the 12th head, Nagamochi, became a priest painter of Buddhist images in Kofuku-ji Temple, and his descendants continued in the same profession.
sen.cmt: Corrected grammar of latter part of sentence.
sen.e: The family started out as court painters, but the 12th head, Nagamochi, became a priest painter of Buddhist images in Kofuku-ji Temple, and his descendants continued in the same profession.

sen.j: 大乗院の絵仏師としての巨勢家は室町末期までしか確認できないが、江戸時代に入っても巨勢家が大乗院の絵仏師の任にあったと思われる。
sen.e: The history of the Kose family as a priest painter of Buddhist images of the Daijo-in Temple could be traced till the end of the Muromachi period, but the family probably continued in charge of the same work in the Edo period.

The history of the Kose family as priest painters of Buddhist images of Daijo-in Temple can be traced up to the end of the Muromachi period, but the family probably continued in the same work into the Edo period.

The history of the Kose family as priest painters of Buddhist images of Daijo-in Temple can be traced up to the end of the Muromachi period, but the family probably continued in the same work into the Edo period.

sen.j: 巨勢公望の門人春日基光は土佐派の流祖となった。
sen.e: KASUGA no Motomitsu, KOSE no Kinmochi's pupil, founded the Tosa school.
KASUGA no Motomitsu, KOSE no Kinmochi's pupil, founded the Tosa school.
KASUGA no Motomitsu, KOSE no Kinmochi's pupil, founded the Tosa school.

sen.j: 巨勢派歴代
sen.e: The successive heads of the Kose school
List of heads of the Kose school in chronological order
List of heads of the Kose school in chronological order

sen.j: 第1世 巨勢金岡（こせの かなおか）
sen.e: The first head of the family (school): KOSE no Kanaoka
The first head of the family (school): KOSE no Kanaoka
The first head of the family (school): KOSE no Kanaoka

sen.j: 大和絵の創始者にて、その家系は古代の名族巨勢氏の家系に連なう。
sen.e: He created "Yamato e" (a traditional painting of the late Heian and Kamakura periods dealing with Japanese thems), and his lineage traced back to a distinguished family of the Kose clan in ancient times.

KOSE no Kanaoka created "Yamato e" (a traditional painting style of the late Heian and Kamakura periods dealing with Japanese themes), and could trace his lineage back to a distinguished family of the Kose clan in ancient times.
sen.cmt: I think "Yamato e" is a painting style. Also altered second half of sentence for readability.
sen.e: KOSE no Kanaoka created Yamato-e (a traditional painting style of the late Heian and Kamakura periods dealing with Japanese themes), and could trace his lineage back to a distinguished family of the Kose clan in ancient times.

sen.j: 貞観_(日本)～延喜年間に活躍。
sen.e: He was active during the Jyogan and the Engi eras (859-922).
He was active during the Jyogan and the Engi eras (859-922).
He was active during the Jogan and the Engi eras (859-922).

sen.j: 第2世 巨勢相覧（こせの おうみ）
sen.e: The second head of the family (school): KOSE no Omi
The second head of the family (school): KOSE no Omi

sen.j: 金岡の長子。
sen.e: The first son of Kanaoka

sen.j: 『源氏物語』に「絵（竹取物語）は巨勢の相覧、手は紀貫之書けり。」とある。
sen.e: "The Tale of Genji" describes that the illustrations for "the Tale of the Bamboo Cutter" were made by KOSE no Omi, and the manuscript by KI no Tsurayuki.
"The Tale of Genji" describes that the illustrations for "the Tale of the Bamboo Cutter" were made by KOSE no Omi, and that the manuscript was written by KI no Tsurayuki.
"The Tale of Genji" describes that the illustrations for "the Tale of the Bamboo Cutter" were made by KOSE no Omi, and that the manuscript was written by KI no Tsurayuki.

The third head of the family (school): KOSE no Kintada

sen.j: 金岡の次子。
sen.e: The second son of Kanaoka
The second son of Kanaoka
The second son of Kanaoka

sen.j: 『日本紀略』にて天暦三年(949)に皇命にて御屏風八帖を画いたと知られる。
sen.e: According to "Nihon Kiryaku" (a chronological summary of the Japanese history), he did a painting on eight folding screens by order of the Emperor in 949.
According to "Nihon Kiryaku" (a chronological summary of Japanese history), he did a painting on eight folding screens by order of the Emperor in 949.
According to "Nihon Kiryaku" (a chronological summary of Japanese history), he did a painting on eight folding screens by order of the Emperor in 949.

sen.e: The third son of Kanaoka

sen.j: 『源氏物語』に「公望が仕れる大局殿の儀式の絵…」とある。
sen.e: "The Tale of Gnji" describes that Kinmochi painted a picture of a ceremony for his lord.
"The Tale of Genji" records that Kinmochi painted a picture of a ceremony for his lord.
"The Tale of Genji" records that Kinmochi painted a picture of a ceremony for his lord.

sen.j: 第5世 巨勢広貴（こせの ひろたか）()弘高・広高と同じ。

sen.j: 『権記』長保四年(1002)花山上皇の勅にて書写山性空上人を画かしめたと知られる。
sen.e: According to "Konki" (the diary written by FUJIWARA no Yukinari), he painted a portrait of Priest Shoku Shonin of Mt. Shosha by order of the retired Emperor Kazan in 1002.
According to "Konki" (the diary written by FUJIWARA no Yukinari), the son of Fukae painted a portrait of Priest Shoku Shonin of Mt. Shosha by order of the retired Emperor Kazan in 1002.
